abstract.text: A specialized view controller for previewing an item.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: can display previews for many common file types, including the following:
Rich text format, or RTF, documents
Text files with a uniform type identifier that conforms to the
3D models in the USDZ format with both standalone and AR views for viewing the model
The list of supported common file types may change between operating system releases. In addition, you can enable previews for your own file types by implementing your own preview extension.

content.text: Providing data to a preview controller

inlineContent.text: To use a preview controller, you need to provide a data source object. The data source provides preview items to the controller and tells it how many items to include in a preview navigation list. If there’s more than one item in the list, a controller displays navigation arrows to let the user switch among the items. If you push a preview controller into view using a navigation controller, you can provide buttons in the navigation bar for moving through the navigation list.
For details on providing items to a preview controller, see

content.text: Previewing items in Mac apps built with Mac Catalyst

inlineContent.text: For Mac apps built with Mac Catalyst, presenting a

and dims the previously active window. However, unlike on iOS devices, where displaying a preview hides the presenting view controller, the previously visible window’s content remains visible in Mac apps built with Mac Catalyst. Be sure the content is appropriate to display while the
In addition, the system doesn’t display a live preview if you embed the
in another view controller. Instead, it displays a thumbnail that matches the size of the preview controller’s view.

abstract.text: A protocol that defines a set of properties you implement to make a preview of your application’s content.
A class that implements the Quick Look preview panel to display a preview of a list of items.
A container view controller that defines a stack-based scheme for navigating hierarchical content.
An object that manages a view hierarchy for your UIKit app.
Presents a view controller modally.
Provide uniform type identifiers that describe file types for storage or transfer.
Create previews of files to use inside your app, or perform simple edits on previews.
A specialized view controller for previewing an item.
Returns a Boolean value that indicates whether the preview controller can display an item.
The item displaying in the Quick Look preview controller.
The index within the preview item navigation list of the item displaying in the Quick Look preview controller.
The preview controller’s data source.
The preview controller’s delegate object.
Asks the Quick Look preview controller to recompute the display of the current preview item.
Asks the preview controller to reload its data from its data source.
The protocol that a data source for a preview controller needs to adopt to provide preview items to the controller.
The protocol that a delegate of a preview controller needs to adopt to handle Quick Look previews.
A scene configuration to preview items at the specified URLs.
Create thumbnail images or previews of common files and custom file types in earlier versions of macOS.

doc://com.apple.quicklook/documentation/.title: Previews or thumbnail images for macOS 10.14 or earlier

abstract.text: An object that manages a view hierarchy for your UIKit app.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The interface an app extension uses to respond to a request from a host app.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A protocol that a class must adopt to allow appearance customization using the [`UIAppearance`](doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIAppearance) API.
A set of methods for adapting the contents of your view controllers to size and trait changes.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
Methods for adding objects to your state restoration archives.
A set of methods that makes the iOS interface environment available to your app.
The protocol you adopt to restore an object’s state from a user activity.
A type that calls your code in reaction to changes in the trait environment.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
